# I Can't Live Without You

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

"I Can't Live Without You"  
---  
[![Al Walser I Can't Live Without You cover
artwork.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1d/Al_Walser_I_Can%27t_Live_Without_You_cover_artwork.jpg/220px-
Al_Walser_I_Can%27t_Live_Without_You_cover_artwork.jpg)](/wiki/File:Al_Walser_I_Can%27t_Live_Without_You_cover_artwork.jpg)  
[Single](/wiki/Single_\(music\) "Single \(music\)") by [Al
Walser](/wiki/Al_Walser "Al Walser")  
Format | [Digital download](/wiki/Music_download "Music download")  
Recorded | September 21, 2012  
[Genre](/wiki/Music_genre "Music genre") | [Eurodance](/wiki/Eurodance "Eurodance")  
Length | 4:21  
[Label](/wiki/Record_label "Record label") | Cut the Bull Entertainment  
[Songwriter(s)](/wiki/Songwriter "Songwriter") | Al Walser, Paul Sissons  
[Producer(s)](/wiki/Record_producer "Record producer") | [Al Walser](/wiki/Al_Walser "Al Walser")  
  
"**I Can 't Live Without You**" is a song by Liechtenstein producer [Al
Walser](/wiki/Al_Walser "Al Walser").

The song was nominated for [Best Dance Recording](/wiki/Best_Dance_Recording
"Best Dance Recording") at the [2013 Grammy Awards](/wiki/2013_Grammy_Awards
"2013 Grammy Awards"). It lost to "[Bangarang](/wiki/Bangarang_\(song\)
"Bangarang \(song\)")" by [Skrillex](/wiki/Skrillex "Skrillex") & Sirah.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Reception
  * 2 Track listing
  * 3 References
  * 4 External links

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Live_Without_You&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Reception")]

The song's nomination for a [Grammy Award](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award")
caused controversy. Philip Sherburne of _[Spin](/wiki/Spin_\(magazine\) "Spin
\(magazine\)")_ noted a lack of notability of Walser compared to
[Avicii](/wiki/Avicii "Avicii"), [Calvin Harris](/wiki/Calvin_Harris "Calvin
Harris"), [Skrillex](/wiki/Skrillex "Skrillex"), and [Swedish House
Mafia](/wiki/Swedish_House_Mafia "Swedish House Mafia"), as they were also
nominated for the same award, writing that the song's "clunky rock/trance
fusion and low-budget video make [Rebecca Black](/wiki/Rebecca_Black "Rebecca
Black")'s '[Friday](/wiki/Friday_\(Rebecca_Black_song\) "Friday \(Rebecca
Black song\)")' sound and look cutting-edge in comparison".[1] Bill Freimuth,
the vice president of the [Recording
Academy](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Recording_Arts_and_Sciences "National
Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences") – which is responsible for the Grammy
Awards – told [MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") Walser "was a very active marketer of his
work, and got his music out to lots and lots of our voting membership, and
they chose to vote for it." He noted that ballot is [audited](/wiki/Audit
"Audit") by [Deloitte](/wiki/Deloitte "Deloitte") and said "they found nothing
really anomalous or wrong with the votes surrounding this nomination."[2]

Speculation surrounding the nomination includes Walser's membership to the
Recording Academy. Walser stated his position as a voter "was only helpful to
the extent that I had access to the other voters, and they could see what I
was doing on a regular basis".[3] [_Billboard_](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\)
"Billboard \(magazine\)") compared the incident to [Linda
Chorney](/wiki/Linda_Chorney "Linda Chorney"), who gained a Grammy Award
nomination the previous year through a similar tactic.[4]
